Editor's note: This story was originally published on July 9
TEL AVIV
column2: Israel – Before I hit the bike path for a long sightseeing excursion in this international hotspot
column3: dressing down in muted colors
column4: a nondescript baseball cap and a relatively cheap watch and shoes was as second nature to me as applying sunscreen.

column1: As a longtime national security journalist who has traveled to some of the world’s grittiest corners
column2: I learned long ago to make sure I’m that person who doesn’t stick out in a crowd and become a target for thieves
column3: terrorists
column4: or kidnappers – whether I’m on an assignment or a family vacation.

column1: Central Intelligence Agency operatives on assignment overseas call it “being the gray man” who blends in and doesn’t alert the world to their American citizenship and all of the assumed wealth and baggage that can bring. I learned about this valuable safety tip during many “Hostile Environment Training” courses I’ve taken over the decades
column2: including some I helped design for young journalists flying off to destinations overseas.

column1: Live updates:Israel orders 'complete siege' of Gaza; at least 9 Americans killed
Learn more: Best travel insurance
'We have to be on guard a lot':Why safety comes first for so many LGBTQ travelers

I was already thinking of brushing up on my travel safety tips when preparing to come to Tel Aviv when I happened upon a new CIA web posting with advice from its officers on how to travel safely and with confidence.
The CIA released these tips – or travel tradecraft
column2: in spy parlance – as part of its ongoing effort to demystify its work in assisting the American public
column3: according to agency spokesperson Walter Trosin.

column1: I found the CIA's best practices
column2: culled from the experience of its officers in the field
column3: are exceptionally helpful
column4: easy to adopt and especially relevant to Americans in these fraught times.

column1: Here’s how to think like a spy on the ground overseas
column2: with some annotation based on my travels as anything but an American James Bond:

column1: ▶ CIA tip: Make a paper and digital copy of your passport. While traveling abroad
column2: it might literally be your ticket home if problems arise. If a hotel desk clerk asks to hold on to your passport
column3: see if they’ll accept the paper copy. While you’re at it
column4: write down some important phone numbers on the hard copy
column5: including emergency contacts and the local U.S. embassy just in case.

column1: Josh's tip: Email yourself the digital copy in case your phone goes missing along with your passport.

▶ CIA tip: Register with your embassy. Think of it as establishing communications with your home base. This enables embassy staff to contact you if there’s an emergency or unfolding crisis. U.S. citizens can also sign up with the State Department’s Smart Traveler Enrollment Program.
▶ CIA tip: Learn some local lingo. Bring a pocket guidebook or phone app so you can pick up key words and phrases.
Josh's tip: My go-to essentials include “thank you
column2: ” “please
column3: ” “hello
column4: ” “goodbye
column5: ” “yes/no
column6: ” “help
column7: ” “bathroom” and “police.” In worst-case scenarios
column8: yelling out “no cash” helps if you believe you might be getting robbed
column9: and “medic” and “hospital” if someone is hurt.

column1: ▶ CIA tip: Know your destination. Bone up not just on travel books but also try to get a sense of the place and the geopolitical issues at play there. The CIA World Factbook is very helpful and publicly available for basic information. The CIA's World Factbook team also has created special travel briefings for many countries.
Josh's tip: Look up the State Department Travel Advisories for your destination
column2: though they often tend to be overly scary and alarmist.

column1: ▶ CIA tip: Scout out local transportation. Upon arrival
column2: ask an airport official or travelers’ aide how much it should cost to catch a public shuttle or taxi to your hotel. Check online sites too. Be sure to negotiate the taxi price before loading your baggage and getting inside. Only use cabs from the official queue – or ride-hailing services from official apps – that are clearly marked and have a functioning meter and the driver’s ID displayed inside.

column1: Josh's tip: Ask ahead of time if they take credit cards or American currency. Even better
column2: stock up on the local currency
column3: preferably at an ATM where you can use a credit card that gets you a better rate than the money changers at the airport.

column1: ▶ Josh's tip: Keep all your luggage close. This is especially the case when getting to and from your hotel. Bags can disappear at the luggage carousel
column2: the taxi stand
column3: hotel lobby
column4: or any number of other places.

column1: Story continues below.

▶ CIA tip: Know your escape route from your hotel room too. Familiarize yourself with emergency evacuation plans. And do a run-through to determine how many doors there are between your room and the nearest stairwell. Could you find it in the dark? While holding your breath in a smoky haze?
▶ CIA tip: Use the elevator
column2: unless it’s an emergency. Using the stairs may be great for exercise
column3: but crimes frequently occur in isolated stairwells.

column1: ▶ CIA tip: Try to reserve a room on a middle floor. Being on the ground floor can leave you vulnerable to break-ins
column2: but many countries’ emergency response personnel aren’t equipped to reach higher than a few floors off the ground.

column1: Josh's tip: If you’re in a particularly strife-torn locale
column2: consider a room in the back of the hotel if you’re worried about car bombs or terrorist attacks. And just know that in some hotspots
column3: bad actors will target hotel restaurants and other places where tourists congregate.

column1: ▶ CIA tip: Lock it up. Automatic locks on hotel room doors can often be forced open
column2: and the chains cut. Use the deadbolt if there is one. Better yet
column3: invest in a cheap and easily portable rubber doorstop; they work amazingly well.

column1: ▶ CIA tip: Beware of unsolicited knocks. Don’t open your hotel door unless you know or can verify who’s on the other side. Be especially wary of unrequested special delivery
column2: maintenance calls
column3: turndown service
column4: or room service. Don’t be shy about calling the front desk to confirm.

column1: ▶ CIA tip: Lock it down. Whether renting a car or taking a taxi
column2: lock the doors and keep the windows rolled up if you sense any danger – or crowds. Carjackers and snatch-and-grab thieves often prey on simple mistakes like an open door or window.

column1: ▶ Josh's tip: When using Uber
column2: Lyft and many other ride-hailing apps
column3: make sure you are getting into the correct car. If something feels wrong
column4: don’t get in.

column1: ▶ CIA tip: Stay alert. CIA officers (the real term for overseas spies
column2: not agents) are trained to be highly attuned to their surroundings to constantly maintain situational awareness. Use all five senses to pay attention to what’s happening around you
column3: and you’ll not only spot telltale signs if something is amiss but retain more of your destination’s unique atmosphere.

column1: Josh's tip: You don’t always need to sit with your back to the wall like Jason Bourne but being able to see the entrances – and know the exits – is important if you need to get out quick.
▶ CIA tip: Be mindful when drinking adult beverages. Spies might swill martinis in the movies
column2: but alcohol impairs alertness and judgment and could put you at risk
column3: especially in an unfamiliar country. Learn the local customs and restrictions on alcohol consumption and follow them closely.

column1: Josh's tip: Make sure you can see your drinks being poured and transported to you to make sure no one is adding any intoxicants. Avoid using or purchasing recreational drugs even if locals insist they’re safe and legal.

▶ CIA tip: Walk the walk. Your confident demeanor on the street is often the best deterrent against criminals. Be the gray man or woman and you won’t look like an easy target. Don’t attract attention by looking confused
column2: lost
column3: or distracted. Avoid poring over maps and phone apps in busy areas. And don’t be flashy. Flaunting extravagant watches and other personal items or cash will attract thieves and opportunists.

column1: ▶ CIA tip: Plan your route and reroute as necessary. Whether traveling by foot
column2: car
column3: or public or private transit
column4: prepare in advance. Bone up on the potentially dangerous parts of town so you can avoid them. Don’t walk alone at night
column5: stick to well-lit areas that aren’t too isolated if you can and know the number of the local authorities just in case. Avoid crowd commotion
column6: as it could mean escalating danger or even a distraction designed to help someone target you.

column1: Josh's tip:  Carry an emergency whistle handy to scare off potential assailants.
With these tips
column2: I spent the day biking throughout Tel Aviv and the nearby port of old Jaffa
column3: home to a vibrant multiethnic community of Muslims
column4: Christians
column5: and Jews. The city was on edge a bit due to a recent wave of terrorist attacks
column6: but I thoroughly enjoyed my time chatting up the locals and sampling their food and drink knowing I was doing everything I could to stay safe.

column1: U.S. airlines have suspended flights to and from Tel Aviv amid the ongoing conflict between Israel and Palestinian militants.
American Airlines
column2: Delta Air Lines and United Airlines have also issued travel waivers allowing passengers scheduled to fly to and from Israel to rebook. United’s waiver also covers flights to and from Amman
column3: Jordan.

column1: “We continue to monitor the situation with safety and security top of mind and will adjust our operation as needed
column2: ” American said in a statement.

column1: Delta said it is suspending operations to and from Israel through Oct. 31.

Our hearts are with those who are impacted as our people work to find safe alternatives for customers trying to depart TLV, a statement from the airline said. "Delta will continue to explore options for customers to safely exit TLV via seats that become available on our partner airlines."

Delta noted that flights to and from Tel Aviv on partner airlines like Virgin Atlantic should remain available and bookable on its website. It also noted some flights through Oct. 17 may inaccurately show up as operating on some platforms but emphasized that those flights are canceled.
United Airlines said its flights will remain suspended "until conditions allow them to resume."
If your flight was canceled by a U.S. airline
column2: you are entitled to a full refund even if you bought a nonrefundable ticket
column3: according to Department of Transportation regulations.

column1: The State Department has also issued travel advisories for the region
column2: urging increased caution for American citizens headed to Israel and the West Bank
column3: and suggesting not to travel to Gaza.

column1: “Terrorist groups
column2: lone-wolf terrorists and other violent extremists continue plotting possible attacks in Israel and the West Bank and Gaza. Terrorists and violent extremists may attack with little or no warning
column3: targeting tourist locations
column4: transportation hubs
column5: markets/shopping malls
column6: and local government facilities
column7: ” the advisory says. “Violence can occur in Israel and the West Bank and Gaza without warning. There has been a marked increase in demonstrations throughout Israel
column8: some with little or no warning.”

column1: The Federal Aviation Administration posted a notice to pilots in the region.

Due to the ongoing conflict situation between Israel and Gaza, operators are advised to exercise extreme caution when operating within the Tel Aviv flight information region, the notice to air missions (NOTAM) issued Saturday said. "Flight crews should remain in contact with air traffic control at all times while operating within the (region)."
Many European and Asian airlines also suspended service to Tel Aviv. Israel’s national carrier
column2: El Al
column3: continues operating flights.

column1: Air France said it suspended services to Tel Aviv “until further notice” after coordinating with French and Israeli authorities.
Germany’s Lufthansa
column2: which suspended flights to and from Tel Aviv until Saturday
column3: said Monday that the decision regarding its planes and those of its subsidiaries was made “due to the still unclear developing security situation in Israel and after an intensive analysis of the situation.”

column1: The Lufthansa Group includes Austrian Airlines
column2: Swiss and Brussels Airlines as well as Lufthansa itself.

column1: Hong Kong’s main carrier
column2: Cathay Pacific Airways
column3: said that “in view of the latest situation in Israel
column4: ” it was canceling its Tel Aviv flights scheduled for Tuesday and Thursday.

column1: Virgin Atlantic canceled its service between London’s Heathrow Airport to Tel Aviv on Monday and Tuesday
column2: as well as the return flight from Tel Aviv to London on Wednesday.

column1: Budget airline Wizz Air
column2: which flies to Israel from Abu Dhabi and more than two dozen European airports
column3: said it was canceling all flights to and from Tel Aviv “until further notice.”

column1: The U.K. discount carrier easyJet said that “due to the evolving situation in Israel
column2: ” it has decided to “temporarily pause operations” its flights from London Luton and Manchester airports to Tel Aviv.

column1: British Airways said it’s planning to continue operating flights to Israel “over the coming days with adjusted departure times.”
Dutch carrier KLM said it’s scrubbing flights to Tel Aviv “until and including Wednesday.”

UPDATE: This story has been updated with news that within hours of publication of USA TODAY's investigation
column2: MSU suspended Coach Mel Tucker without pay.

column1: Two years ago
column2: one of the nation’s star college football coaches and a prominent rape survivor teamed up to fight the culture of sexual violence in sports.

column1: Their partnership should have been a force for good. Instead
column2: it has devolved into scandal
column3: with the activist accusing the coach of the same misconduct that both of them preached against.

column1: The accused is Mel Tucker
column2: the head football coach at Michigan State University and one of the highest paid coaches in all of sports. Accusing him is Brenda Tracy
column3: a rape survivor who has made educating athletes about sexual violence her life’s work.

column1: Over eight months
column2: they developed a professional relationship centered on her advocacy work. Tucker invited Tracy to campus three times – twice to speak to his players and staff and once to be recognized as an honorary captain at the team's spring football game.

column1: But their relationship was upended during a phone call on April 28
column3: Tracy says in a complaint she filed with the university’s Title IX office in December that remains under investigation.

column1: According to her complaint
column2: Tracy sat frozen for several minutes while Tucker made sexual comments about her and masturbated. His violation
column3: she said
column4: reopened 25-year-old wounds from her rape by four men – two Oregon State University football players
column5: a junior college player and a high school recruit.

column1: “The idea that someone could know me and say they understand my trauma but then re-inflict that trauma on me is so disgusting to me
column2: it’s hard for me to even wrap my mind around it
column3: ” she told USA TODAY. “It’s like he sought me out just to betray me.”

column1: In his statements to the Title IX investigator
column2: Tucker acknowledged masturbating on the call but said Tracy grossly mischaracterized the episode. According to him
column3: they had consensual “phone sex.”

column1: “Ms. Tracy’s distortion of our mutually consensual and intimate relationship into allegations of sexual exploitation has really affected me
column2: ” Tucker wrote in a March 22 letter to the investigator. “I am not proud of my judgment and I am having difficulty forgiving myself for getting into this situation
column3: but I did not engage in misconduct by any definition.”

column1: Michigan State hired an outside Title IX attorney to investigate the complaint. She finished her investigation in July. A formal hearing to determine whether Tucker violated the school’s policy banning sexual harassment and exploitation is scheduled for Oct. 5 and 6
column2: during the Spartans’ bye week.

column1: The stakes are high for everyone.

Tracy says Tucker is following through on a threat to ruin her career and reputation by painting her as a woman who mixes professional and personal relationships and files false reports. She fears he will undo her legacy.
Tucker
column2: who signed one of the most lucrative contracts in college sports history two years ago
column3: could lose out on the roughly $80 million he is owed if Michigan State fires him for cause
column4: which would be a stunning fall from the elite ranks of college coaches.

column1: Reached by USA TODAY on his cellphone Saturday night
column2: Tucker hung up after a reporter mentioned the case.

column1: Hours after USA TODAY published its investigation
column2: the university suspended Tucker without pay
column3: pending a resolution of the Title IX case.

column1: “This step
column2: suspending Mel Tucker without pay
column3: is … necessary and appropriate for today's circumstances
column4: ” Interim President Teresa Woodruff said at a Sunday evening press conference. “These actions are not taken lightly.”

column1: USA TODAY typically does not identify people who allege sexual harassment. Tracy agreed to be identified and shared more than 1
column2: 200 pages of case documents.

column1: Title IX
column2: the federal law banning sex discrimination in education
column3: requires schools to investigate allegations of sexual harassment that took place in the context of a school program or activity. Such claims are inherently difficult to adjudicate because of many of the factors at issue in this case: a lack of eyewitnesses and recordings
column4: the passage of time and the thorniness of litigating consent.

column1: Adding to the uncertainty
column2: the institution tasked with sorting out the facts is perhaps best known for missing repeated opportunities to stop one of the most prolific sexual abusers in American history.

column1: For nearly two decades
column2: Michigan State leaders failed to act on complaints against Larry Nassar
column3: the disgraced former U.S.A. Gymnastics and campus physician accused of sexually assaulting more than 300 female athletes under the guise of medical treatments. He has been sentenced to a minimum of 100 years in prison.

column1: Amid its efforts to rebuild trust among students
column2: employees
column3: alumni and the East Lansing community
column4: Michigan State's leaders must now decide whether the face of its prestigious football program is guilty of sexually harassing one of the country’s most influential advocates against gender-based violence.

column1: For some
column2: how the university navigates the crisis will send a clear message about its commitment to progress.

column1: “This goes beyond coach Tucker and Brenda Tracy
column2: ” said Jennifer Gomez
column3: a Boston University professor who researches the effects of interpersonal trauma and violence. “What happens here has the potential to be very healing or very harmful for lots and lots and lots of other people.”

column1: Tracy and Tucker met in August 2021 during her first visit to Michigan State
column2: after a mutual acquaintance introduced them.

column1: Standing before a packed auditorium in the Spartans’ football operations building
column2: Tracy told a gut-wrenching story of turning her pain into purpose two decades after filing a police report saying she had been gang-raped as a 24-year-old mother of two.

column1: At the end
column2: she challenged the “good men” in the room to use their privilege and influence to educate themselves and call out bad behavior.

column1: By then she had delivered versions of the speech more than 100 times to at least 40
column2: 000 athletes and coaches. Michigan State paid her a $10
column3: 000 speaking fee.

column1: Tucker was in his second season as head coach. A former University of Wisconsin-Madison defensive back
column2: he had spent two decades coaching defenses for 10 college and NFL teams before landing the top job at the University of Colorado in late 2018. Michigan State lured him away a year later by doubling his salary.

Tucker and Tracy “hit it off” immediately

column1: The university tapped Rebecca Leitman Veidlinger

column3: Michigan-based Title IX attorney

column1: A former Indiana sex crimes prosecutor who now heads a private practice
column2: she also previously worked in the Title IX offices at Michigan State and the University of Michigan.

column2: including three of Tucker’s assistants who had been involved in coordinating and canceling her campus visits.

column1: Jacqueline Swanson

Although Veidlinger had interviewed all six of Tracy’s witnesses before the end of January

column2: and how does it expect its 20

Tucker sat down for his interview on March 22.
