column1: Call me old fashioned
column2: or maybe I have a terrible case of clumsy thumbs. If I have a choice between texting or a phone call to converse with someone
column3: I choose a call most of the time.

column1: It’s faster
column2: easier
column3: and I can do it safely while driving
column4: walking
column5: or folding laundry. Also? If someone calls and doesn’t leave me a voice message
column6: I will likely assume they don’t need to talk with me.

column1: According to the latest rules of smartphone etiquette − and my 22-year-old daughter − I’m doing it all wrong.
As new technology changes
column2: so do the rules of engagement around it
column3: and it’s harder than ever to keep up!

column1: While common sense should dictate that it’s not polite to talk on our cell phones while we’re in a bathroom or use the speakerphone in a movie theater
column2: clearly
column3: some people missed that memo.

column1: Doing either is considered baseline rude at best
column2: but I witnessed both in the last week alone. If some people are still so oblivious to the most obvious tech-related social faux pas
column3: how are we supposed to pick up on the new stuff
column4: like whether we should text someone before we call them or when to use the latest iOS 17 video voicemail feature?

column1: “Much like everything else
column2: behavior evolves based on the situation
column3: ” national etiquette expert Diane Gottsman wrote via email. When everyday situations change for the masses
column4: such as more people using FaceTime and making videos in public places
column5: there are social nuances that are simply more polite
column6: sensitive
column7: and respectful to others
column8: she explained.

column1: Before we go through specifics
column2: though
column3: it’s important to note that what works for close friends and family is not the same for business or professional relationships. Also
column4: age can play a role in what’s socially acceptable.

column1: For instance
column2: I can’t get all judgey if someone texts or DMs in all lowercase without punctuation anymore. My 23-year-old production assistant recently told me it’s kind of rude to add a period even when I’m texting her. It’s like I’m being passive-aggressive and not as sincere.

column1: “You can’t assume everyone understands or communicates the same way. Many abbreviations are age-related or even depend on a person’s country of origin. It’s important to mirror the communication style of the person you speak with
column2: ” Gottsman added
column3: especially in client or work situations.

column1: Context is key
column2: but ever-evolving rules of modern-day etiquette are also good to know. Here are some of the most important.

column1: Gottsman
column2: who owns the Protocol School of Texas
column3: said you should now text someone before you call them. “It’s a social courtesy that allows the receiver to let you know if they are available. If they don’t respond
column4: you can assume it’s a bad time to talk
column5: ” she said.

column1: That would drive me insane
column2: I wrote back to Gottsman. It adds extra work to respond
column3: and isn’t that what voicemail’s for − especially now that iOS 17 shows a transcript of what the person is saying as they’re leaving a message − so you can decide if you want to pick up?

column1: “You would assume that if someone doesn’t pick up
column2: it’s because they can’t take your call or are in a place where they can’t speak freely. However
column3: many people continue to call over and over again
column4: which is a big cell phone ‘no
column5: ’” Gottsman clarified. “People's lives are busier now
column6: and we are all aware of how intrusive a phone call can be. A quick text first to see if someone is available alleviates an interruption in a meeting
column7: at dinner
column8: or during a job interview.”

column1: Exceptions:
It’s OK to call first if you’re reaching out to friends or family or if it’s an emergency.
Also
column2: you don't have to pick up if someone calls you and it’s not a good time.

column1: Responding to a call with an automated text response is fine
column2: especially if you add a custom reply. That happens to me a few times every day. If I’m already on the phone
column3: I often type in a speedy personal response
column4: such as
column5: ‘I’m on the phone now
column6: but will call you back as soon as I’m off.’

column1: When is the right time to leave a voicemail? If you ask someone in their teens
column3: or even 30s
column4: they will likely say
column5: “never.”

column1: Gottsman also says it’s never okay to leave a long-winded voicemail and agrees that most don’t get listened to. “Most people see you have called
column2: and rather than listen to the voicemail
column3: just call you back anyway. It saves time.”

column1: It’s also essential to leave your full name and callback number
column2: even though it often appears on screens automatically. “Don’t assume the person will recognize you just by your first name or that your message or call back number will go through clearly. Make sure they can reach you without creating extra work for them
column3: ” Gottsman noted.

column1: Exceptions:
Emergencies
column2: important work messages
column3: and emotions are often best handled via voice versus text.

column1: It’s also OK to leave a voice message for family −anytime and any length.
“There are people who want to hear your voice and enjoy listening to your message
column2: ” Gottsman added. “But for someone you don’t know as well
column3: ask them how they prefer to communicate.”

column1: Again
column2: it’s fine if it’s someone close to you. But as a general rule
column3: no. Arrange a video call first.

column1: I recently went down an hours-long rabbit hole on this topic on both Reddit and Quora
column2: and wow
column3: does it make people mad when you FaceTime them without permission. “It’s the same as walking into someone’s house uninvited
column4: ” wrote one person on a Reddit AITA subgroup.

column1: Another new iOS 17 update lets you leave a video message when someone doesn’t answer your FaceTime call. If you’re traveling and want to show something special to a loved one
column2: show off a baby’s first steps to grandparents
column3: or even your amazing new highlight to your BFF
column4: it’s fine. (As long as you’re following the etiquette rules of FaceTiming in public
column5: which is next on this list.)

column1: But most people who aren’t related to or in love with you don’t want a video message. “Don’t assume everyone enjoys watching you on video
column2: ” Gottsman added.

column1: That goes tenfold for a NSFW video! Just don’t.
Too many updates?:Apple is urging everyone to update iPhone and iPad iOS (again). Why you should do it now.
Best charging cable:In need of an iPhone 15 charging cable? Here's how to find the best USB-C charger cord
The answer here depends on where you are and who’s around you. Most people think it’s rude to FaceTime in a public place
column2: especially without headphones on or when anyone else is in the background other than you.

column1: It’s considered good form to keep a distance of at least 10 feet from the nearest person when you’re on your smartphone
column2: especially if you’re using video of any kind. Most of us tend to talk louder on cellphones than in real life
column3: so talk quietly and be aware of your surroundings before you turn your video camera on
column4: period.

column1: The number of people FaceTiming or doing social media videos in front of the Mona Lisa at the Louvre when we visited there this time last year was so incredibly cringey; it took away from the experience overall.
Consider going somewhere else when your actions take away from other people’s enjoyment of any public space. This includes blasting your music
column2: playing video games
column3: or watching videos without headphones or sound effects turned off.

column1: Here are more smartphone manners that haven’t changed:
It’s (still) not okay to have your smartphone at the dinner table. The only exception is if you’re expecting a life-or-death text or call. In that case
column2: let everyone around you know you might have to answer your phone.

column1: Shhhh! Use your “inside voice
column2: ” and watch your language. Cursing might be the new “hello” for some people
column3: but experts
column4: it’s still considered poor manners in most public situations.

column1: Put your phone away and do not check it during meetings
column2: Gottsman reiterates. “Cell phones are a distraction
column3: especially in work situations. Looking down or checking your smartphone or smartwatch appears as if you are distracted
column4: impatient
column5: or checking to see who is texting you
column6: ” she said.

column1: It’s also best to keep business correspondence professional. “This includes emails as well as texts. If you have a fun
column2: relaxed relationship with your client and they use emojis
column3: you can feel free to respond in kind. But don’t overdo it. A well-placed emoji is fine
column4: but allowing the emojis to take over your message is unprofessional.”

column1: Beware of ‘phubbing
column2: ’ which is snubbing other people for your phone. It happens all the time
column3: too. Parents check social media when their kids need attention. Couples do it during “snuggle time.” I just did it a little while ago to my dog. She was staring at me to go for a walk
column4: and I was distracted by a hilarious TikTok video.

column1: Not only are these behaviors rude
column2: but studies show they break up relationships
column3: cause crowd fights
column4: and might even hurt people — and pets — you care about the most

column1: .Jennifer Jolly is an Emmy Award-winning consumer tech columnist and on-air correspondent. The views and opinions expressed in this column are the author's and do not necessarily reflect those of USA TODAY.
This week Apple rushed out an emergency patch to fix a serious security flaw for iPhones and iPads.
The zero-day vulnerability which allows attackers to elevate privileges may have already been exploited
column2: Apple said.

column1: Apple patched the flaw in the iOS 17.0.3 and iPadOS 17.0.3 updates. It did not provide additional details.
“This update provides important bug fixes
column2: security updates and addresses an issue that may cause iPhone to run warmer than expected
column3: ” Apple said.

column1: So what’s with all the Apple security updates?
Apple’s cat-and-mouse game with zero-day hackers seems to be picking up.
According to SecurityWeek
column2: this was the 16th documented zero-day exploit against Apple’s iOS
column3: iPadOS and macOS-powered devices.

column1: The list of affected devices include: iPhone XS and later as well as iPad Pro 12.9-inch 2nd generation and later
column2: iPad Pro 10.5-inch
column3: iPad Pro 11-inch 1st generation and later
column4: iPad Air 3rd generation and later
column5: iPad 6th generation and later
column6: and iPad mini 5th generation and later.

column1: Should you worry about all of these iOS updates? In general
column2: yes.

column1: “We all have to realize there is an industry out there that is actively targeting our devices and all the personal information we have on them
column2: ” said researcher John Scott Railton
column3: a senior researcher with Citizen Lab at the University of Toronto’s Munk School.

column1: But we should not be alarmed by the frequency of the Apple security patches
column2: according to Railton. The growing number of updates are a sign that Apple is working hard to keep our devices secure
column3: he said.

column1: “Apple is
column2: from my perspective
column3: really leaning into hunting for and quickly fixing this kind of bug
column4: ” Railton said. “It’s a little bit like
column5: why do you hear so many sirens? Because the ambulance service is finally going to people’s houses when they call.”

column1: But it’s not just down to Apple
column2: Railton said. There are steps we can all take to protect our devices from incursions.

column1: No one gets excited about updating their phone. But
column2: said Railton
column3: “every time you update
column4: you make your device more secure.”

column1: First
column2: you should make sure automatic updates are turned on.

column1: Install updates as soon as you hear about them. Here’s how:
If you are at higher risk or are just concerned about security
column2: use lockdown mode on your iPhone. Here’s how.

column1: “What researchers have found is that lockdown mode blocks a lot of sophisticated attacks
column2: even without the phone being updated. Of course
column3: people need to update their phone. But lockdown mode in some cases would have blocked attacks even before Apple knew about this specific exploit or there was a patch released
column4: ” Railton said. “It radically increases the security of your device and makes it way more expensive for bad actors to hack into your stuff.”

column1: Security Planner is a free guide from Consumer Reports that was originally developed and maintained by the Citizen Lab. It provides information on identity theft and ransomware
column2: plus tips on devices such as smart speakers
column3: baby monitors
column4: and smart TVs.

column1: Turn on multifactor authentication on all accounts that offer it
column2: the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) recommends.

column1: Use strong passwords that are long
column2: random
column3: and unique to each account
column4: and use a password manager to generate them and to save them
column5: says CISA
column6: which is part of the Department of Homeland Security.

column1: Think before you click
column2: CISA says. Be cautious with unsolicited emails or texts or calls asking for personal information. Don't click on links or open attachments from unknown sources.

Sometimes you’ve just got to go for what your heart desires. That’s what a New York 8-year-old did when his dad was leaving for work.
Barefoot and still in his pajamas
column2: Isaiah Lobdell ran out of his house on Aug. 3 as his dad was pulling out of the family’s driveway to start his workday as an ironworker.

column1: After successfully flagging his dad down
column2: his father got out of his truck
column3: picked the boy up and the two shared an adorable
column4: tight hug.

column1: The moment was captured on the family’s doorbell camera and uploaded to TikTok. It has amassed 1.5 million views and nearly 183
column2: 000 favorites since then.

column1: “The ‘I’ve gotta go to work’ hugs always hit a little different
column2: ” Tyler
column3: the boy’s father
column4: captioned the upload.

column1: Made up of dad Tyler
column2: mom Hailey and sons Isaiah and Hudson
column3: the Lobdell family live in Constantia
column4: just north of Syracuse.

column1: The family says hugs are a huge part of their mornings.
“I probably have to give like five hugs a morning to each kid
column2: ” Tyler said. “Anytime they ask for it
column3: I always go for it. I never turn down a hug.”

column1: Watch:Double proposal caught on camera at Disneyland's Sleeping Beauty Castle
Isaiah told USA TODAY Monday evening that he ran out to see his dad because he just wanted to.
“He forgot to give me a hug and I wanted one
column2: ” Isaiah said. “He was going off for work so I was like ‘I’ve got to go get him now.’”

column1: “Did he forget to give you a hug or did he forget to give you a tenth hug?” his mom
column2: Hailey
column3: laughed.

column1: Isaiah loves his dad and he just likes hugging him
column2: he said. His younger brother Hudson does too.

column1: Tyler
column2: the boys’ father
column3: said when he saw his son running out of the house
column4: he knew he wanted another hug. Once the sweet moment was over
column5: something told him to check the family’s doorbell footage.

column1: He was originally going to save the recording for himself but after watching it “a bunch of times
column2: ” he decided to share it on social media.

column1: Tyler’s wife
column2: Hailey
column3: said the family is shocked by how many people have watched and commented on the video. Moments like this are a reality check for many people
column4: she said.

column1: “It reminds people of what they have
column2: what they used to have
column3: what they wish they had
column4: and for some reason
column5: people really gravitated toward us
column6: ” she said. “It was a good reminder for a lot of people to just slow down or appreciate when you still have these things or look back fondly on memories.”

column1: His wife said it’s amazing that such a simple moment between a dad and son could inspire so many people.
“We kind of have referred to it as the hug heard ‘round the world
column2: ” she said. “It was just such a simple thing between a kid and a dad
column3: just something that happens with us all the time. When you really stop and think about it
column4: it inspires a lot of gratitude.”

The Lobdells save moments like these to look back on in the future. Their boys are growing so quickly and sometimes
column2: they’re amazed by how much they’ve changed in just a year or so.

column1: “It's crazy
column2: ” their mother said. “You look back on a video from a year ago and now that they're a little older
column3: you think ‘They haven't changed that much.’ But when you really look back at pictures and videos
column4: you realize they have grown and changed so much.”

column1: The boys like looking back at their old photos and videos. The family often sits down to look at photos and reflect on memories they all share.
“The way our phones are now
column2: with such nice cameras
column3: we're really trying to take advantage of being able to take pictures and videos
column4: ” Tyler said.

column1: Sometimes they hear the way the boys used to say phrases as babies and it makes them laugh and smile so much that they become part of daily conversation
column2: the parents said.

column1: “They're super creative kids
column2: ” their mom said. “They want us to feel love. They want to feel love.”

column1: The first and third-grade boys are very personable too
column2: their mother said.

column1: “No one would accuse them of being shy
column2: ” she laughed.

column1: The boys have “huge imaginations
column2: ” their mother said. They love building and they have tons of blocks they like to play with. Their house is full of their latest construction projects
column3: their parents said.

In addition to the hug video that captured the hearts of millions online

column1: Tyler said the boys asked to make YouTube videos last year. They get together with cousins and other family members to do activities outdoors such as ice fishing
column2: magnet fishing and more.

column1: The idea is to get parents to go outside with their kids

column1: “We try to think of fun

column4: ’” Tyler said.

column1: The family appreciates the kind words people have sent their way since their TikTok video went viral.
“It's reached so many people and so many people have felt it so deeply

column1: WASHINGTON – The Supreme Court is being asked to weigh a ban on “conversion therapy” − the practice of trying to change a person's sexual orientation or gender identity − in an appeal that tests the court's appetite for engaging this term in the legal battle between religion and LGBTQ+ rights.
Long discredited and already banned for minors in about half of U.S. states
column2: the practice of using ''treatment'' to make a gay or lesbian person straight has reemerged as the Supreme Court has become more conservative and receptive to appeals dealing with religious freedom. Opponents say the practice can involve electrical shocks and nausea-inducing drugs as well as psychoanalysis and counseling.

column1: Brian Tingley
column2: a licensed family counselor in Washington state
column3: is challenging the state's ban on the practice for people under 18
column4: claiming it violates his free speech and religious rights. The law
column5: he told the Supreme Court this year
column6: "forbids him from speaking
column7: treating his professional license as a license for government censorship."

column1: Preview:The Supreme Court gets back to work. Here are the cases to watch.

Opponents of the practice say states have banned it for minors because it increases the risk of depression and suicide for LGBTQ+ young people. Washington's law doesn't apply to churches or religious groups
column2: only to therapists who are licensed – and regulated – by the state.

column1: This is a dangerous practice, said Laurel Stine
column2: chief policy officer for the American Foundation for Suicide Prevention. "The Supreme Court has not taken up any of these challenges before
column3: and we are confident that
column4: if they do
column5: we will win."

column1: The justices were set to discuss the case privately Friday and could announce as soon as Tuesday whether they will decide it or allow a lower court ruling against Tingley to stand.
The court has declined to hear similar challenges in the past
column2: leaving other state bans in place. But those challenging the bans note that the Supreme Court also recently handed down a decision that appeared to strengthen First Amendment speech protections in the workplace.

column1: As the Supreme Court has become more conservative in recent years
column2: it has taken a keen interest in cases involving religious freedom.

column1: Tingley argues that a 2018 decision by the Supreme Court involving anti-abortion pregnancy centers should weigh in his favor. In that case
column2: a 5-4 majority of the court’s conservatives said a California law that required the pregnancy centers to notify clients about publicly funded abortion and contraception services likely violated the First Amendment.

column1: More:Supreme Court backs web developer who didn't want to create same-sex wedding sites
While California argued its law regulated "professional speech
column2: such as what a therapist might say to a client during a session, the Supreme Court ruled it had never carved out a separate category of workplace speech subject to different First Amendment protections. Then in 2020, a federal court of appeals in Atlanta relied on that Supreme Court decision to block enforcement of similar conversion therapy" bans in parts of Florida.

column1: Tingley is represented by the religious rights group Alliance Defending Freedom
column2: which has filed several successful religious appeals at the Supreme Court in recent years. John Bursch
column3: the group’s senior counsel
column4: said he fears governments could try to label other speech “professional conduct” in an effort to engage in widespread censorship.

column1: Bottom line: The government cannot censor a counselor’s speech, Bursch said. "Washington's counseling censorship law violates freedom of speech and harms counselors and their clients."
A U.S. District court in Washington dismissed Tingley’s case in 2021. The U.S. Court of Appeals for the 9th Circuit sided against him last year.
Washington Attorney General Bob Ferguson
column2: a Democrat
column3: did not respond to a request for comment.

column1: The case is Tingley v. Ferguson.
Religious groups and individuals have collected significant wins at the Supreme Court in recent years
column2: expanding religious protections in the workplace
column3: knocking down anti-discrimination laws intended to protect LGBTQ+ people
column4: and opening the door for taxpayer money for schools that offer religious instruction.

column1: In one high-profile case last year
column2: the Supreme Court sided with a web designer who wants to decline to create websites for same-sex weddings because of her religious beliefs. The designer
column3: Lorie Smith
column4: who was also represented by Alliance Defending Freedom
column5: successfully argued that Colorado's anti-discrimination law compelled her to make speech she disagreed with.

column1: Laws along these lines have done much to secure the civil rights of all Americans, Justice Neil Gorsuch wrote for a 6-3 majority. "But in this particular case Colorado does not just seek to ensure the sale of goods or services on equal terms. It seeks to use its law to compel an individual to create speech she does not believe."
Tingley's attorneys suggested in court filings that the decision for Smith works so strongly in his favor that the Supreme Court could decide the case without hearing arguments.
But so far this term
column2: the court has yet to grant a religious-freedom case.

column1: Critics say they believe the law − and the science − is on their side when it comes to "conversion therapy" bans. The American Psychological Association
column2: the American Psychiatric Association
column3: the National Association for Social Workers and other leading medical groups have all repudiated the practice.

column1: Casey Pick
column2: director of law and policy for The Trevor Project
column3: which focuses on suicide prevention among LGBTQ+ young people
column4: said every court that has considered a statewide ban has upheld it.

column1: There is no reason the (Supreme) Court should not do the same here, she said
column2: "and ensure that LGBTQ young people across the country continue to be protected from unprofessional
column3: unscientific and deeply harmful practices."

column1: If you or someone you know may be struggling with suicidal thoughts
column2: you can call the U.S. National Suicide Prevention Lifeline at 988 any time day or night
column3: or chat online.

column1: Every time he goes on social media
column2: Aziz Abu Sarah feels sick to his stomach. The Palestinian man has Jewish friends who've lost family members. Friends taken hostage.

column1: I worry for them like I worry for my Palestinian friends who are in Gaza now, living under bombardment of air strikes, says the author of "Crossing Boundaries: A Traveler’s Guide to World Peace." "We need to see the nuances."
Social media
column2: however
column3: often renders nuance obsolete.

column1: Misinformation and propaganda about the Israel-Hamas conflict – which has resulted in more than 900 Israelis and upwards of 680 Palestinians dead
column2: just days into a new war – fills social media feeds and shows no signs of slowing. Some posts mention the death toll on only one side. Some ignore the civilians taken hostage. Some fail to mention Israel's occupation of Gaza. Some don't account for why Jewish people around the world grow afraid.

column1: These posts often come from those far away from the conflict
column2: like in the U.S.
column3: who feel like they have to say something for the sake of seeming involved. But declaring support for one "side" over the other and listing out-of-context information about Israelis and Palestinians may hurt more than help your cause.

column1: Infographic social media posts trying to detail a topic as fraught
column2: as frustrating
column3: as long-lasting as the Israeli-Palestinian conflict will always lack critical details due to social media's bite-size commentary nature. Experts warn you should seek greater context before sharing anything. It's perfectly acceptable – and even preferred – for you to stay quiet if you don't know enough about what you're talking about.

column1: Not everything is black and white, Abu Sarah says. "And to me
column2: it's most painful when I see people I know
column3: people who I respect
column4: people who I love
column5: who have fallen for these (posts) and feel that they need to serve 'their country
column6: their cause
column7: their people
column8: ' whatever
column9: by spreading misinformation. It's devastating to me."

column1: Abu Sarah worries the propaganda and misinformation could be result in deadly consequences
column2: for those in the Middle East and elsewhere. "People will read it
column3: get angry and do things."

column1: The latest:Israel regains control over Gaza Strip border; rocket attacks intensify
Websites like Instagram and X
column2: formerly known as Twitter
column3: speak in soundbites
column4: not dissertations.

column1: You only have a certain amount of space where you can post your tweet or one photo or two, and it doesn't necessarily lend itself to any kind of nuance, or real, significant conversation, says Shaya Lerner
column2: the director of Israel Affairs at the Anti-Defamation League.

column1: The sites have historically faced difficulty combating antisemitic and Islamophobic posts.
Plus
column2: "we know that algorithms can trend toward feeding people polarizing and extremist content to keep them clicking
column3: says Sarah Parkinson, assistant professor of political science and international studies at Johns Hopkins University. The lack of moderation makes it easy for individuals and organizations to harass people into silence."

column1: Social media infographics
column2: of course
column3: can be helpful resources in educating those completely uninformed. It's when people don't go beyond theses sources that trouble looms. Rabbi Rick Jacobs
column4: President of the Union for Reform Judaism
column5: says: "There are positive
column6: important things that we can do with postings on social media. But the boundaries are not clear. And the abuses are quite evident."

column1: Jacobs says some of the posts he's seen have hurt.

I, every day, would not only defend but really strongly defend the rights of Palestinians to have dignity and human rights, Jacobs says. "But for me to say that (Hamas) this group of terrorists who are trying to literally murder women and children and families and rip families apart and take them captive
column2: and (for some on social media) to be able to say with a straight face
column3: this is such a noble thing they're doing. That just offends every sensibility I have."

column1: Many argue that the decades of violence against Palestinians under Israeli occupation warrants mentioning to better contextualize the attack on Israel.
The cancer patients in Gaza who can't receive medical treatment, because they're not allowed out of the enclave, and yet they die as a result of that, that's violence, says Saree Makdisi
column2: UCLA professor and author of "Palestine Inside Out: An Everyday Occupation."

column1: He wants to see instances like these illustrated more on social media
column2: which is often too simplified: "It's not all big explosions
column3: and fires and rockets and tanks and this kind of thing
column4:
he adds.
How to cope:The videos out of Israel, Gaza are graphic, but some can't look away
So if social media infographic posting and re-posting isn't the right answer, what is?
My advice to people is always to read a broad spectrum of media outlets
column5: including media from the region
column6: and to understand what it is that they’re reading
column7: Parkinson says. Search the outlet
column8: read a Wikipedia page on it; don’t just go to one news source to understand any situation. Verify that what you’re reading a credible outlet or source. Seek out local voices and establish who they are."

column1: Makdisi adds: "It's important to understand the context and the history of this violence
column2: where it's come from
column3: where it's going
column4: and what the possible solutions are
column5: that involve peace and justice for all sides." Granted
column6: what peace and justice look like
column7: and if it's even achievable
column8: differs depending who you're asking.

column1: That doesn't mean social media is useless
column2: either. Abu Sarah suggests following those who have different points of view. He also recommends sharing stories of unity: "There are today
column3: Israelis and Palestinians who are doing the impossible to support each other. I can tell you dozens of these stories and yet unfortunately
column4: those are the missing stories
column5: whether it's on social media or in our discussions."

column1: If you decide to post something
column2: don't expect everyone to agree with you. "Remember that many on social media already have their minds made up and will respond to what they 'think' you are saying rather than your actual words
column3:
says psychologist Reneé Carr.
When you stop thinking of the other side" as human
column4: you've lost. Abu Sarah adds: "If you think one side is a pure evil and one side is pure good
column5: you're missing the story."

column1: 'The fear is real':Menorahs mean more this Hanukkah amid rising antisemitism
A year ago
column2: President Joe Biden’s plan was to forgive up to $20
column3: 000 in student loan debt for tens of millions of Americans.

column1: With that plan now extinct
column2: the first of several conversations to hash out a new strategy for erasing loan balances en masse begins Tuesday.

column1: Creating clearer regulations will ensure the authority to waive student debt is used in a fair and lawful manner, said James Kvaal
column2: under secretary of education. "We believe that doing so will strengthen the entire student loan system
column3: help us tackle pervasive problems in the system
column4: and help ensure postsecondary education is a path to opportunity for more students."

column1: As the process of negotiated rulemaking
column2: or neg reg as it’s sometimes called in federalese
column3: gets underway
column4: tens of millions of Americans are wrestling with student loan payments for the first time in more than three years. Social media is littered with evidence of confusion about the size of monthly payments. Some people say they are puzzled about why they are being billed at all. One set of borrowers has their payments set to zero because of a new federal repayment option called SAVE that aims to be more generous than any other.

column1: The negotiators begin their conversation at 10 am Eastern time and it will be livestreamed with a chance for the public to weigh in. Here’s what you need to know:
Biden's new student debt relief plan5 key takeaways from the first day of public input
The process the Biden administration has turned to is called negotiated rulemaking. It has been used many times over the years to draft rules related to higher education
column2: including on how Title IX law on sexual assault is applied at schools and colleges and how well colleges produce graduates whose jobs can cover their student debt.

column1: The people who will hash out the student loan plan applied or were nominated to participate and then were selected by the Education Department. They represent different groups who have a stake in student loans
column2: such as borrowers
column3: student loan servicers and colleges and universities. Some of the members include Wisdom Cole
column4: national director of the NAACP Youth & College Division; Yael Shavit
column5: an assistant attorney general in the Consumer Protection Division of the Massachusetts Attorney General's Office; and Jada Stanford
column6: a student at Stephen F. Austin State University in Texas.

column1: This is a complete list of the committee members
column2: including alternates.

column1: Their meeting agenda doesn’t give very much away. But the focus of the virtual meeting will be wide-reaching
column2: with discussion reserved for each of the five guiding questions mapped out by the department.

column1: The questions are described in this issue paper published late last month. They are
column2: in short:

column1: Public comment comes at the end of each day of conversation. To sign up to speak
column2: send your name and
column3: if applicable
column4: organization to negreghearing@ed.gov no later than 12:00 p.m. Eastern time on the day of the meeting.

column1: The negotiators have to come up with a plan to which each committee member agrees. If they don’t arrive at a consensus
column2: the Education Department will come up with its own proposal. Either way
column3: there will be another opportunity for the public to comment on what is developed before it’s finalized. Congress will then have the opportunity to review the rule
column4: and has the option of passing a joint resolution to overturn it.

column1: A final rule must be published by Nov. 1 for it to go into effect in July of the following year. This rulemaking schedule is a big reason the Biden administration is so intent on publishing a rule developed under its Education Department. If the process goes according to plan
column2: the earliest borrowers would see forgiveness is summer of 2024.

column1: When the Supreme Court struck down Biden’s original plan this past summer
column2: it ruled that student loan debt relief could not happen through the president’s executive authorities the way he’d hoped. That means the only viable routes are through Congressional legislation – which given partisan gridlock is all but impossible – or federal higher education policy changes
column3: a.k.a. neg reg.

column1: If a rule isn’t finalized through this neg reg series and a Republican wins next year’s presidential election
column2: the chances of broad student loan forgiveness becoming reality are even slimmer.

column1: First
column2: sign up to watch the negotiators discuss policies that could make large-scale loan forgiveness a reality. You’ll need to register at this link.

column1: The first meeting spans over two days
column2: Tuesday and Wednesday
column3: for five hours each – from 10 am to noon Eastern
column4: then 1 pm to 4 pm.

column1: The next meeting is scheduled for Nov. 6-7
column2: and the one after that for Dec. 11-12. Both of the sessions
column3: like the one that kicks off Tuesday
column4: will be virtual and include opportunities for the public to comment.

column1: Biden has a Plan Bfor mass student loan forgiveness. It could be excruciatingly long
WASHINGTON — Despite the House being frozen without a speaker
column2: Congress is in for a hectic week as Republicans scramble to find a new leader after the historic ouster of former Speaker Kevin McCarthy
column3: R-Calif.

column1: House Republicans have a schedule: They'll meet Tuesday night to hold a candidate forum where prospective speakers will make their pitches to fellow GOP lawmakers. Next
column2: they'll hold a secret vote on a nominee Wednesday night.

column1: It's unclear when the House will hold an official speaker election. But the ongoing war between Israel and Palestinian militants could pressure lawmakers to pick up the pace and elect a new speaker so the House can act on the war
column2: especially if they need to approve humanitarian aid or other crucial measures.

column1: Here’s what to know going into a chaotic week in Congress.
Following McCarthy’s historic ouster as speaker last week
column2: leaving the House virtually powerless
column3: House Republicans went home to decide on next steps to crown a new leader and get the lower chamber moving again.

column1: So far
column2: two GOP lawmakers have emerged as possible successors to McCarthy: House Majority Leader Rep. Steve Scalise
column3: R-La.
column4: and House Judiciary Committee Chair Rep. Jim Jordan
column5: R-Ohio.

column1: Scalise was largely expected to run for speaker after McCarthy was removed
column2: given his position as the No. 2 ranking House Republican. The Louisiana lawmaker
column3: who suffered a near-death experience in 2017 after a gunman opened fire at a practice session for the Congressional Baseball Game
column4: has commanded respect from virtually every corner of the House GOP conference.

column1: Jordan
column2: who first came into Congress as a conservative bomb-thrower and was a founding member of the ultra-conservative House Freedom Caucus
column3: has been a close ally of McCarthy and House GOP leadership. Chair of the powerful House Judiciary Committee
column4: Jordan is currently one of the lawmakers spearheading House Republicans’ impeachment inquiry into President Joe Biden.

column1: Scalise and Jordan have both already received endorsements from GOP lawmakers
column2: revealing House Republicans' dilemma: The conference remains divided
column3: and it’s unclear who can become speaker.

column1: House Republicans will hold a closed-door meeting Tuesday night and host a candidate forum to hear from Scalise
column2: Jordan and other prospective speakers.

column1: Then on Wednesday night
column2: GOP lawmakers will hold an internal secret ballot vote where they decide on a nominee to put forward on the House floor. Under their current rules
column3: a nominee only has to earn a simple majority of votes from the secret ballot.

column1: But even if a candidate emerges victorious as the nominee Wednesday night
column2: lawmakers aren't obligated to support that person. Other officials could still be nominated in the speaker election on the House floor
column3: which could happen anytime following the secret ballot vote.

column1: House Democrats are largely expected to stay out of the process. House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries
column2: D-N.Y.
column3: said Sunday his conference won’t take part in the “Republican civil war.”

column1: “It's not my job at this moment to weigh in to the politics that are taking place in the House Republican Conference
column2: other than to make clear that it's time for the GOP to end the Republican civil war
column3: in order for us to be able to come together in an enlightened and bipartisan way to get things done for everyday Americans
column4: ” Jeffries said Sunday on CNN’s “State of the Union.”

column1: At the same time
column2: as it becomes more clear that no candidate so far can earn the majority of votes needed to become speaker
column4: McCarthy has shown willingness to be reinstated as the lower chamber's leader.

column1: “That’s a decision by the conference
column2: ” McCarthy said Monday morning at a press conference reiterating U.S. support for Israel. McCarthy has yet to endorse a candidate for speaker and noted that “96 percent” of House Republicans stood behind him as he attempted to quell the conservative rebellion that ultimately removed him from his post.

column1: The surprise attack by Hamas on Israel over the weekend has added a new dimension to an already unprecedented series of events in the House. Without a speaker
column2: the House is unable to pass any legislation
column3: including emergency aid to Israel
column4: a U.S. ally.

column1: McCarthy on Monday lamented that it was “wrong” for him to be ousted by a sliver of House Republicans – just eight GOP lawmakers voted to remove him – now that the lower chamber is paralyzed as the conflict in Israel unfolds.
“We are living in very dangerous times. The pettiness has got to stop
column2: ” McCarthy said.

column1: Rep. Mike Lawler
column2: R-N.Y.
column3: a moderate GOP lawmaker
column4: has shown support for McCarthy to return to the speakership and decried his removal as “idiotic
column5: ” as news broke on Hamas’ attack.

column1: “Removing (McCarthy) from office
column2: mid-term
column3: was idiotic
column4: ” Lawler said in a post on X
column5: formerly Twitter. “Doing so as Israel faces an all out attack is dangerous. Uncertainty and chaos in the U.S. breeds vulnerability around the world. The House should immediately reinstate McCarthy and stop screwing around.”

column1: But the urgency of the conflict isn't guaranteed to push GOP lawmakers to quickly throw their support behind a new leader. Speaker pro tempore Rep. Patrick McHenry
column2: R-N.C.
column3: is currently serving in a limited role as acting speaker
column4: and given the historic nature of the situation
column5: it's not clear if McHenry can put any legislation on the House floor.

column1: Following the September 11 terrorist attacks
column2: every House speaker has created a backup list of temporary successors intended to ensure the speakership is never vacant in the case of a catastrophic event. The list has never been used until last week when McCarthy was ousted.

column1: Considering the nature of the backup list
column2: McCarthy suggested McHenry had some sort of power to lead the House and take action on the conflict in the Middle East.

column1: “I know this is new territory. It was created after 9/11. I don’t understand why the speaker pro (tempore) couldn't lead as well
column2: ” McCarthy said. “We should have a resolution on the floor condemning what’s taken place so the rest of the world understands
column3: we should supply and make sure that there’s no question and no doubt that Israel will never be overwhelmed when it comes to ammunition.”

column1: Closing arguments are expected to begin Tuesday in the trial of one current and one former Aurora
column2: Colorado
column3: police officer charged in the death of 23-year-old massage therapist Elijah McClain in 2019. The officers have pleaded not guilty to criminally negligent homicide
column4: manslaughter and assault.

column1: In Washington
column2: jurors in the trial of three Tacoma Police Department officers are expected to hear more testimony in the case of 33-year-old Manuel Ellis
column3: who died in 2020 after telling officers multiple times he couldn't breathe during a struggle that was captured on camera. The officers face second-degree murder or first-degree manslaughter charges and have pleaded not guilty.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: in Tennessee
column3: five former Memphis police officers charged in the beating and death of 29-year-old Tyre Nichols in January are waiting to learn when they will stand trial in state court. The officers have pleaded not guilty to second-degree murder and other charges in the case.

column1: Across the United States
column2: the number of police officers charged with violent on-duty crimes
column3: including murder
column4: manslaughter and assault
column5: has increased in recent years in part because of increased public scrutiny
column6: new technology and legal changes that have helped make prosecutions possible. Still
column7: such charges for police officers remain rare and convictions are rarer still
column8: data shows.

column1: There's a demand for criminal prosecution, said Kate Levine
column2: a professor at the Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law in New York. "And so prosecutors are looking to charge police officers when they wouldn't have in the past
column3: and/or because of police bodycams or citizens taking videos
column4: evidence comes up to contradict these claims
column5: where it may not have in the past."

column1: Police kill more than 1
column2: 000 people each year
column3: according to databases created by the Washington Post and civil rights organization Campaign Zero.

column1: Since 2005
column2: 185 nonfederal law enforcement officers have been arrested on charges of murder or manslaughter as a result of an on-duty shooting
column3: according to Philip Matthew Stinson
column4: a professor of criminal justice at Bowling Green State University in Ohio who tracks the criminal arrests of nonfederal police officers.

column1: Stinson's data shows the number of officers charged in on-duty fatal shootings has generally increased
column2: from a low of one in 2011 to a high of 21 in 2021. But Stinson said he doesn't consider that a remarkable shift in part because the number of police killings has also increased in recent years.

column1: According to The Washington Post
column2: fatal police shootings increased from 995 in 2015 to a record high of 1
column3: 096 in 2022. The Mapping Police Violence database created by Campaign Zero found police killed a record-high 1
column4: 250 people last year
column5: up from 1

column1: The number of officers charged in terms of a percentage has stayed flat, it's still under 2% of the cases ... so from where I sit things have not changed, Stinson said.
Since 2005
column2: 59 officers charged with murder or manslaughter in connection with an on-duty shooting have been convicted of a crime
column3: but only six were convicted of murder
column4: according to Stinson's data. The criminal cases of 45 officers arrested on charges of murder or manslaughter after an on-duty shooting are pending.

column1: The data doesn't reflect officers charged in non-shooting deaths
column2: such as in the deaths of McClain
column3: Ellis
column4: Nichols or George Floyd
column5: who was murdered in Minneapolis in 2020.

column1: What has changed
column2: according to Stinson
column3: is the number of officers arrested for other violent crimes
column4: such as assault. He said the most recent data he has analyzed
column5: which has not yet been peer-reviewed
column6: shows that from 2014 to 2018
column7: there was a significant increase in officers arrested in connection with other on-duty violent crimes.

column1: Stinson said that spike could be the result of an increase in cameras
column2: including cellphone
column3: doorbell and body-worn cameras
column4: as well as increased scrutiny of police use of force sparked by the 2014 killings of Tamir Rice in Ohio and Michael Brown in Missouri
column5: which helped fuel the Black Lives Matter movement.

column1: Their on-duty violence is being more closely scrutinized by prosecutors and their own agencies, Stinson said.
In most cases
column2: on-duty fatal shootings are determined to be legally justified.

column1: On Friday
column2: for example
column3: officials in Georgia announced the state troopers who shot a 26-year-old environmental activist who was protesting the construction of a police and fire training center near Atlanta will not face criminal charges because their use of deadly force was "objectively reasonable."

column1: In Philadelphia
column2: former police officer Mark Dial was initially charged with murder
column3: voluntary manslaughter
column4: aggravated assault
column5: simple assault
column6: reckless endangering of another person
column7: and official oppression in connection with the shooting of 27-year-old Eddie Irizarry on Aug. 14. But last month
column8: a judge agreed with the defense's argument that Dial acted in self-defense and dismissed the charges.

column1: When cases do make it to trial
column2: Stinson said
column3: juries are still "very reluctant to second-guess the split-second decisions of on-duty police officers in potentially violent street encounters."

column1: But as public scrutiny has increased
column2: some states have made changes to laws surrounding the use of deadly force by police.
voters in Washington approved Initiative 940
column3: which removed the requirement that prosecutors prove an officer acted with malice before murder charges can be filed − something no other state required. Ellis' case marked the first time the state's attorney general's office criminally charged police officers with the unlawful use of deadly force and the second time an officer has been charged in a homicide in Washington since the change took effect.

column1: What 940 established doesn't make it easy − I think it's really important to say that − but it establishes the possibility of holding police criminally accountable for negligent behavior, said Martina Morris
column2: a member of the Washington Coalition for Police Accountability.

column1: Seven states also have changed laws governing when police are justified in using deadly force
column2: according to Everytown for Gun Safety. When California in 2019 changed the standard for which a police officer can use deadly force to when it’s “reasonable’’ to when it’s “necessary
column3: Robert Weisberg, law professor and faculty co-director of the Criminal Justice Center at Stanford University in California, told USA TODAY the change moved the law in the direction of making it more feasible to prosecute officers for homicide."

column1: Abdul Nasser Rad
column2: managing director of research and data at Campaign Zero
column3: said it's still unclear what the impact of those changes has been.

column1: The jury's still out on that, he said.
Because it can take years for internal investigations and subsequent criminal cases to be resolved
column2: it's difficult to determine whether it's getting easier to prosecute police officers
column3: Rad said.

column1: I don't think it's fair to say whether it's gotten worse or better. It's such a small number, and there's so many missing values.
Contributing: Jorge L. Ortiz and Thao Nguyen
column2: USA TODAY; The Associated Press

column1: Lior Onaly-Kelsey celebrated their 15th birthday two weeks ago. They also celebrated the end of a years-long battle against Greater Albany Public School District.

column2: 353 in damages

A 6-year-old girl with a rare neurological disease recently underwent a 10-hour surgery in California where half of her brain was disconnected in an effort to help cure her.
Brianna Bodley underwent a procedure called a hemispherotomy on Sept. 28 to treat a rare disease called Rasmussen's encephalitis
column2: according to a GoFundMe page created by her mother
column3: Crystal Bodley.

column1: The surgery was performed by Dr. Aaron Robison at Loma Linda University Medical Center in Loma Linda
column2: California. Robison told ABC 7 that "just disconnecting it [the brain] is enough to stop the disease completely and essentially
column3: potentially cure it."

column1: According to the GoFundMe page
column2: Brianna was diagnosed with epilepsy in August 2022 after suffering from nighttime seizures and being hospitalized for five days.

column1: In September 2022
column2: she was once again admitted to the hospital
column3: this time for eight days
column4: and was diagnosed with Rasmussen's encephalitis.

column1: After several seizure medications failed to work
column2: it was recommended that Brianna undergo the operation.

column1: Crystal Bodley said on the GoFundMe page that the entire left side of Brianna's body is "turned off due to disconnecting half of her brain."
WHAT IS BRAIN FOG?:Five expert recommended steps to get rid of brain fog.
According to the National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke
column2: Rasmussen's encephalitis is a very rare
column3: chronic inflammatory neurological disease that usually affects only one half of the brain.

column1: It most often occurs in children under the age of 10 but can also affect adolescents and adults.
The disease is characterized by frequent and severe seizures
column2: inflammation of the brain
column3: mental deterioration and progressive loss of neurological functions including motor skills
column4: speech and eventual paralysis on one side of the body
column5: according to the NINDS.

column1: A hemispherotomy
column2: the surgery that the young girl went through
column3: involves removing half of the brain's cortex
column4: or outer layer
column5: and the procedure is used "predominantly in children who have seizures that do not respond to medication because of damage that involves only half the brain
column6: as in Rasmussen's encephalitis
column7:
according to NINDS.
COVID-19, RSV, flu or a cold?Figuring out what your symptoms mean this fall and winter
According to an Oct. 3 update by Crystal Bodley on the GoFundMe page, Brianna was out of the ICU and had been transferred to a normal hospital unit in the children's hospital.
Brianna will then be transferred to inpatient rehab, where she will learn how to walk and use her left arm and undergo speech therapy, according to the update.
Her mother Crystal also has an Instagram page that document's Brianna's journey and road to recovery.
The latest post on Oct. 9 reads: Pushing through these days trying to learn how to walk again and seeing things that are on her left side. She only sees what's right in front of her and to the right. Everyday we see little progress of her getting better but
column8: still a long journey to go with tons of physical therapy
column9: speech therapy and occupational therapy."

The USA TODAY Opinion section publishes analysis
column2: argument and essays on a wide variety of subjects. We're looking for timeliness (pegged to news)
column3: persuasion pitched to the other side
column4: new information
column5: novel arguments
column6: revelatory insights
column7: passion without partisanship
column8: first-person experience
column9: original reporting that reveals fresh angles and makes news
column11: and/or a topic that will drive conversation on social media and in the real world.

column1: We accept only pieces that are submitted exclusively to USA TODAY. We do not accept material that has been published on blogs
column2: social media or anywhere else.

column1: Columns typically run 550 to 750 words. They should be pasted directly into an email and sent to theforum@usatoday.com. Pieces should include links (URLs
column2: not headlines or footnotes) to back up quotes and factual material. People featured in columns must be identified by their real
column3: full names.

column1: We do not publish open letters
column2: class projects or material that has been submitted to multiple outlets. Rebuttals to editorials and columns published in USA TODAY should be submitted as letters to the editor
column3: not as full-length op-eds.

column1: Due to the volume of submissions
column2: we can’t respond to all columns sent to us. If our Opinion team is interested in yours
column3: you will hear from us within three business days.

column1: Submissions may be edited for accuracy
column2: clarity
column3: style
column4: standards and length.

column1: Please include with your submission a short biography
column2: two sentences at most
column3: to run at the end of your column
column4: as well as a current photograph
column5: to which you own publishing rights. If you or a business
column6: trade group or other institution with which you are associated stands to gain financially or in any other way from your column
column7: you should disclose that information in detail. In most cases
column8: it should also be included in the body of the piece or in the author's biographical information.

column1: Columns are accepted for online publication; print publication is not guaranteed. All columns published by USA TODAY are available for use online and in print by the more than 250 properties in the USA TODAY Network. They include Austin; Bergen County
column2: New Jersey; Burlington
column3: Vermont; Cincinnati; Columbus
column4: Ohio; Des Moines; Detroit; El Paso
column5: Texas; Indianapolis; Louisville
column6: Kentucky; Memphis
column7: Tennessee; Milwaukee; Nashville
column8: Tennessee; Phoenix
column9: Reno

column1: Authors may post their columns elsewhere 48 hours after they are published at USA TODAY. By submitting a column to USA TODAY and agreeing to its publication
column2: authors are granting exclusive rights to the piece to the USA TODAY Network for 48 hours and non-exclusive rights thereafter.

column1: To get a sense of our range
column2: preferences and requirements
column3: check out our op-ed section
